title: 110_hr3357
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that the United States is facing a crisis in writing skills in schools and the workplace, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not ready for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills result in high private-sector costs for training. Writing is essential for employment and promotion, and is a key feature in educational standards. The National Writing Project has been the only national program addressing the writing problem in schools since 1973. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, is the sole national program addressing writing issues in schools. It has shown significant improvements in student writing performance and classroom practices. Over 135,000 teachers benefit from its programs annually in various disciplines across all 50 states. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, addresses writing issues in schools and benefits over 135,000 teachers annually in various disciplines across all 50 states. Teachers benefit from programs in mathematics, science, history, civics and government, geography, reading and literature, technology, performing arts, and foreign languages. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, aims to expand its network of sites across the United States to provide teachers with access to writing programs. The subpart focuses on maintaining high-quality sites, disseminating effective practices, and coordinating activities with the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, aims to expand its network of sites across the United States to provide teachers with access to writing programs. SEC. 2332 focuses on maintaining high-quality sites, disseminating effective practices, and coordinating activities with the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Secretary can award a grant to the National Writing Project to enhance writing teaching in classrooms. The grant requires the grantee to partner with educational providers for teacher training programs in effective writing approaches. In this section, contractors (institutions of higher education or nonprofit educational providers) will establish and operate teacher training programs for effective writing approaches. The Secretary will provide funds for the Federal share of the program costs, and grantees must meet conditions set by the Secretary for compliance. Teacher training programs authorized in this section will be conducted during the school year and summer months, training teachers from kindergarten to college. Selected teachers will join a National Writing Project teacher network to conduct writing workshops for other teachers in the area served by each site. Grantees must meet conditions set by the Secretary for compliance and provide necessary technical assistance. The Federal Share for teacher training programs authorized in this section is 50% of the costs to the contractor, with the Secretary having the authority to waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis. The Federal share for teacher training programs is 50% of the costs to the contractor, with a maximum limit of $150,000 for one contractor or $300,000 for a statewide program. The Secretary can waive this requirement based on financial need, and a National Advisory Board will be established by the National Writing Project. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board consisting of national educational and writing leaders to advise on student writing and teaching issues. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board to advise on student writing and teaching issues, review programs, and support development. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs to specify funds expended. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board to evaluate teacher training programs and specify funds expended. The Secretary will reserve funds for this evaluation for fiscal years 2008 and beyond. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board consisting of leaders in writing research to review and recommend applications for funding. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board to review and recommend applications for funding. The Board will review applications and recommend them for funding by the National Writing Project. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for the following 5 years.
